replies.bodyText: Yes. Using a key based on a properties object here is scary since the object's structure is controlled by lombok. The key would be somewhat "non-deterministic". Using an LDAP url as a String is safer, and possibly slightly faster as a lookup key.

replies.bodyText: Do you want to convert connectionFactory to a separate bean? I think this is a overkill to create a separate bean just to wrap connectionFactory into a DisposableBean.
replies.author: leeyc0

replies.bodyText:
Not quite. Let me clarify: There is a bean somewhere that is creating an instance of LdapUserGraphicalAuthenticationRepository, right? Inside that bean, you need to build the connection factory (as you're doing above in the ctor) and then pass to the ctor here as an argument.
This is so that,

Building "bean" instance should happen during the configuration of the bean itself.
Doing this allows you to delete the manual ctor and use lombok directly to generate it. Fewer LOC.
Makes it easier to write unit tests, in case something has to be mocked down the line.

I think the same pattern more or less applies to other areas in the patch.

timeline.bodyText:
This is not a good pattern. Here's what you should do instead:

Remove the PersonDirectoryAttributeRepositoryPlanConfigurer from the class
Create a Bean of type PersonDirectoryAttributeRepositoryPlanConfigurer. Mark as conditional.
Inject and qualify personDirectoryAttributeRepositoryPlanConfigurerListConnectionFactoryListBean into that bean.
Register the ldap attribute repository into the plan as usual.

timeline.bodyText: Managing the connection factory should be the responsibility of the LDAP DAO itself. On dispose, you should call the plan for each LDAP DAO to invoke each DAO to destroy/close, and the DAO will know what to do on close. Consider merging with master once where you can take advantage of the DAO#close() ops for LDAP DAOs, and also you'd have the ability to filter attribute repositories by a type predicate.
